lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
When working with JSX, we can only ever return one element.

We end up wrapping our elements in one parent element, like a div, to return them as JSX.

Make sure to pick <div>, followed by </div>.

lessons.title: Intro - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Instead of returning a div, we can use React fragments. Fragments let us group multiple elements without adding extra nodes to the DOM.

A fragment is written by <> and </>. Add a fragment around the three elements to allow us to return them.

Make sure to pick <>, followed by </>.

lessons.title: Intro - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Fragments are useful when a component needs to return multiple elements, as React components can only return one element by default.

Make sure to pick < followed by > and then <, /, >.

lessons.title: Intro - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
<> and </> are only the shorthand. We can also use the full <React.Fragment> and </React.Fragment> syntax.

Make sure to pick <React.Fragment>, followed by </React.Fragment>.

lessons.title: Intro - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
React fragments are lightweight by design. We can't add attributes like className or style. However, we can set a key.

When we want to set a key, we can't use the shorthand <>, but we have to use the <React.Fragment> with an explicit key prop.

Make sure to pick key followed by = and then {, key, }.

lessons.title: Intro - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
React requires key props on list items to help it efficiently update and reorder elements without causing issues in the DOM.

Add the fitting key property with its value to the three jokes.

Make sure to pick key="joke1", followed by key="joke2", and finally key="joke3".

lessons.title: Intro - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Notice we use multiple fragments, all wrapped in one outer fragment, with unique keys for efficient updates and a clean DOM.

Make sure to pick <>, followed by </>.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Wrap multiple React components in a single parent element using fragments to return them correctly.

Make sure to pick <>, followed by </>.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
What happens if you try to return two sibling elements without wrapping them?

You get a syntax error, as you must only return one elementThey display next to each otherThey merge into one elementNothing happens

You get a syntax error, as you must only return one element.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use React fragments to return multiple elements without adding extra divs.

Make sure to pick < followed by React.Fragment and then >, <, /, React.Fragment, >.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following is the correct shorthand syntax for a React fragment?

<> </><React.Fragment></React.Fragment><div></div><fragment></fragment>

<> </>.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Add a key property to the fragment.

Make sure to pick key, followed by =, and finally "star-wars-meeting".

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
When should you use a key prop with React fragments?

When displaying elements of a listWhen styling with CSSWhen using a single elementWhen using functions

When displaying elements of a list.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
Write a React component that uses both shorthand and full React fragment syntax.

Make sure to pick <>, followed by </React.Fragment>.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
Identify the true statement about full React fragment syntax.

It allows adding a key propIt accepts all HTML attributesIt adds a node to the DOMIt is always necessary to use

It allows adding a key prop.

lessons.title: Lesson #16
lessons.interactiveContent:
Complete the code to list hobbies with React fragments and keys.

Make sure to pick < followed by React and then ., Fragment, key, =, "hobby1", >.

lessons.title: Lesson #17
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the benefit of using React fragments?

They don't add extra nodes to the DOMThey replace CSS stylesThey make code run fasterThey are always visible in the UI

They don't add extra nodes to the DOM.
